html:
A round-up of notable broker activity this morning from Europe's top-ranked* analysts:


** HSBC says Carl Zeiss Meditec's AFXG.DE new product launches, innovation-fuelled growth and the new CEO "deserve the benefit of the doubt", and raises German medical technology firm to "hold" from "reduce"

** HSBC ups Euronext ENX.PA to "buy" from "hold" as it sees good risk-reward profile, noting its conservative targets can be seen as the floor for any expectations as the European stock exchange operator has a strong track record of over-delivering (Full Story)

** RBC ups France's Sodexo EXHO.PA to "sector perform" from "underperform" on potential food services reboot with imminent new CEO (Full Story)

** Deutsche Bank cuts British asset manager abrdn ABDN.L to "hold" from "buy" as its proposed acquisition of Interactive Investor highlights concerns around value and group targets


INITIATIONS AND REINSTATEMENTS

** Credit Suisse starts "high-quality" pure-play renewables business EDPR EDPR.LS with "neutral", pointing to its already-priced-in pipeline growth and risks from new entrants that may look to list renewables divisions

** CS prefers EDP EDP.LS, which owns 75% of EDPR and prices in three years of renewables growth compared with 10 years for pure-play EDPR

** Barclays initiates Daimler Truck Holding DTGGE.DE with "overweight" (Full Story)

** Jefferies launches coverage of Allfunds ALLFG.AS with "buy" seeing a significant opportunity for the to globalise its business

** Berenberg starts Aalberts AALB.AS with "buy", saying the Dutch manufacturer is set to benefit from attractive secular trends as the pandemic recedes (Full Story)

** Deutsche Bank resumes coverage of German real estate company Vonovia VNAn.DE with "buy" rating citing its undervalued shares versus peers (Full Story)

** Citigroup re-establishes coverage of Aroundtown AT1.DE with "buy", citing improved sentiment around values and rents, as well as potential positive impact from share buyback, focus on corporate governance and disclosure removing legacy concerns

** UBS starts Kingfisher KGF.L with "neutral" saying British home improvement retailer is making progress to accelerate growth but may to underperform expectations given growing competition and its exposure to weaker-growth-profile DYI


(*Analyst rankings from Thomson Reuters StarMine. The scale is from 1-star to 5-star with 5 being the best. Analysts are ranked on earnings accuracy as well as relative performance of recommendations over trailing 12-month & 24-month periods.)



(Reporting by Dagmarah Mackos, Anita Kobylinska)

(( dagmarah.mackos@tr.com ; anita.kobylinska@tr.com ))
